headline.text: Chris Lang mentioned you in a comment.

contentSecondaryText.text:
If I were stuck scaling Shopify, I would attend The DTC Growth Summit before buying another course or watching another video.

 Get in a room with people actually building Shopify brands
 Learn what is working right now, not theory
 See real funnels, offers, and dashboards
 Ask questions you cannot ask on YouTube
 Understand how traffic, creative, and conversion connect
 Learn how operators think, not how influencers talk
 Build relationships that shortcut years of mistakes
 Leave with tactics I could implement immediately
 Raise my standards by proximity to real builders

I will be speaking at The DTC Growth Summit.
Grab your ticket in the comments and I will see you there.

successToastText.text: Thanks. Your feedback helps us improve your notifications.

headline.text: Julius Wesche (PhD) 🌏 mentioned you in a comment.

contentSecondaryText.text:
𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐡𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐭 𝐠𝐨𝐚𝐥𝐬 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐠𝐞𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐭𝐨 10.000 𝐟𝐨𝐥𝐥𝐨𝐰𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐨𝐧 𝐋𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐞𝐝𝐢𝐧
Most of us set goals like:
I want more visibility.
I want more followers.
I want more impact.

These are outcome goals. They feel good. But they change little.

LinkedIn growth is driven by behavior, not ambition.

If we do not build a process or a new habit, our chances of ever reaching those outcomes are low  no matter how serious we are.

The fix: Keeping our outcome goals. But execute them through habit goals.

𝐈𝐧𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐨𝐟:
 I want 10,000 followers.
𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞:
  a set number of posts per week (for example 2-3)
  one repeatable format
  one clear target group (maximum two)

Once you set the routine and you get better over time, growth becomes a side effect of routine.

And if you do not believe me, believe Adam Grant:
behavior-change goals are roughly three times more effective than outcome-only goals.
(Link to his post in first comment.)

So looking into 2026, what hat are your process goals?

successToastText.text: Thanks. Your feedback helps us improve your notifications.

contentPrimaryText.text: Thanks Nem Ng. Very much appreciated.

headline.text: Mahima More mentioned you in a comment.

contentSecondaryText.text:
How I went from 0 to 12K followers on Instagram in 7 months of consistent posting

I just hit 12,000 followers.

The first 6 months
Steady growth.

The last 30 days
6,000 new followers.

Same account. Same niche. Same effort.

What changed was how I worked.

Heres exactly what worked:

1. I became obsessed with my analytics
I started reviewing them weekly, then monthly.
The data told me what was working, what was average, and what was dead weight.

I doubled down on winners.
Dropped what clearly wasnt working.
Tweaked average posts until they performed better.

No guessing. Just data-led decisions.

2. I cracked how Trial Reels work
Once I understood the pattern, I could create low-effort Reels that still got strong reach.

I started posting 23 Trial Reels a day.
More content led to more visibility.
More visibility led to more engagement.
More engagement led to follower growth.

Volume works when you already know what performs.

3. I stayed close to whats working in my niche
I consistently observed other creators.
Which formats were repeating?
Which hooks were stopping the scroll?

I did not copy.
I adapted what worked to my voice and audience.

4. Social listening changed everything
I read comments.
I used Stories to ask questions.
I paid attention to DMs.

Then I built content around what people were already asking for.

Stop guessing what your audience wants.
They are telling you every day.

The bottom line
Those first few months were not wasted.
They were for testing, learning, and building a system.

Once the data was clear, growth compounded fast.

Consistency + analytics + listening = results.

contentPrimaryText.text: Nem Ng Thanks, its been less about speed and more about building systems that bring the right audience. 🙃
